newsitem.title: CHINA: China vows nuclear safety, may build more plants.
newsitem.headline: China vows nuclear safety, may build more plants.

text.p: China's top nuclear official has pledged to ensure nuclear safety of all nuclear power plants at the start of a year of hectic construction, the Xinhua news agency said in an overnight report.

With China's nuclear industry launching several construction projects this year, it was essential to maintain nuclear safety, Jiang Xinxiong, president of the China National Nuclear Corporation, told a meeting in Beijing on Tuesday.

"It is necessary to ensure the safe and stable operation of the Qinshan and Daya Bay nuclear power plants," he said, referring to China's two existing plants, one in eastern Zhejiang province south of Shanghai and Daya Bay in southern Guangdong province that neighbours Hong Kong.
"The safe operation of the two plants has stepped up China's confidence in building more nuclear power plants in coastal areas," Jiang was quoted as saying.
Both plants maintained stable and safe operation last year, with both being refuelled and overhauled for a second time, he said.

In 1997, China would push ahead with the second and third phases of the Qinshan plant, involving installation of two 600 megawatt and two 700 megawatt reactors, as well as the Ling'ao expansion of the Daya Bay plant and construction of a Russian-supplied plant at Lianyungang in eastern Jiangsyu province, he said.
